chargeHist.descr: Homicide by Intoxicated Use of Vehicle

result.execSummary:
The defendant Willie D Cotton III was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Homicide by Negligent Operation/Vehicle, a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.10(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Provide a biological specimen for DNA analysis if not already done so.
Pay the costs, fees, assessments and surcharges.
DOC to collect monetary sums/amounts at a rate to be determined by DOC of prison funds. Balance during the term of Extended Supervision. Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment.

superMiscConds.notes:
No illegal substances.
No Contact Order with any members of the victim's family.

Mental health evaluation.  Comply with any recommended treatment and/or therapy.
Take all medications as prescribed.
AODA assessment.  Comply with any recommended treatment. Absolute sobriety.

supervisions.notes: On April 17, 2017:   Pursuant to Wisconsion Statutes section 973.176 the Court advised defendant that as a convicted felon he may never possess a firearm, ammunition or body armor; also advised that his voting rights are suspended and may not vote in any election until his civil rights are restored.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Willie D Cotton III

records.addlTxt:
A petition for sentence adjustment was filed with the court.
The petition for sentence adjustment is denied because it is not in the public interest.
The court finds that the full time designated for confinement is necessary to punish and deter the defendant.  It would unduly depreciate the seriousness of the offense if the defendant did not serve 100% of the confinement time as ordered by the court.  Adjusting the confinement time would compromise the intent of the court and defeat the purpose of the sentence, which was punishment, deterrence and community protection.  In addition, the conduct report from November 2018 does not reflect well on the defendant's ability to follow the rules.

-  signed by the Court and filed.  Copies mailed to the parties.

Defendant Willie D Cotton in court with Attorney Lauren Stuckert and Attorney Andrew Mishlove.  Paul Leonard Tiffin appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Sentencing proceeds.  State has complied with victim notification.  Statements by Janice S., Larissa R., Paulette R., Janet S., Jennifer B., the State, defense counsel, John L., William W., Jolene C., and defendant.

-  Court sets Restitution at $0 (zero)

COURT ORDERS defendant to serve a term in the Wisconsin State Prison system - TOTAL LENGTH OF SENTENCE -  7 and 1/2  years with  6  days credit -  INITIAL TERM OF CONFINEMENT -  2 and 1/2 years  -  EXTENDED SUPERVISION -  5 years.  

Court finds defendant is NOT  eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and is NOT eligible for the Substance Abuse Program.

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION:  
-  Mental Health evaluation and comply with any recommended treatment and/or therapy
-  Take all medications as prescribed
-  AODA assessment and comply with any recommended treatment
-  Absolute Sobriety
-  No illegal substances
-  No Contact Order with any members of the victim's family
-  Pay the costs, fees, assessments and surcharges during the term of extended supervision.  Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment.

COURT ORDERS:
-  defendant to provide a biological specimen for DNA analysis (if not already done so)
-  DOC to collect monetary sums/amounts (at a rate to be determined by DOC) of prison funds.

Appeal rights given.  Written Explanation of Determinate Sentence and Notice of Right to Seek Postconviction Relief received and filed.  Copies given to the defendant.

Defendant Willie D Cotton in court with attorney Andrew Mishlove.  Michael Jerome Lonski appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Case in Court for Jury Trial. Parties have come to a resolution in this matter. Case proceeded to Plea Hearing. 

AS TO COUNT 1:  Defendant changes his/her plea to NO CONTEST. Defendant was advised of constitutional rights and maximum penalties, waived all rights, plead NO CONTEST and was examined as to the plea.  Plea Questionnaire/Waiver of Rights and Addendum received and filed.  Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis for the plea.  Defendant further advised that if he/she is not a US citizen deportation is possible.  Court found defendant guilty as charged in the Information and ordered entry of Judgment of Conviction. Pursuant to Wisconsin Statutes section 973.176, the Court advised defendant that as a convicted felon he/she may never possess a firearm, ammunition or body armor. Court advised defendant that his/her voting rights are suspended, and may not vote in any election until his/her civil rights are restored.


Case is adjourned for sentencing in Branch 28.
